snippet.title: 'I was ready to give up on my dream'
snippet.content: THE idea for COYO announced itself, like all great ideas, at three o'clock in the morning. I had been retired for a year, filling my days with home renovations and gardening. But that just wasn't enough. Once the idea was planted, I was in the kitchen every day experimenting with different recipes. Our kitchen was often filled with home-made yoghurt machines churning out coconut yoghurt. I worked for six months to perfect the original recipe before we were ready to take the idea commercial. It still brings tears to my eyes when I talk about the day the first commercial batch of COYO was created. Things weren't going as planned and I was on the verge of giving up and tipping my dream down the drain, but I persevered. It was lucky I did as just after my dream started slipping away, I looked down into the yoghurt vat and saw the creation of the very first coconut yoghurt in Australasia. The rest is history. Of course, with all new products there was a lot of initial feedback for the product. We welcomed this feedback and used it to improve our original recipe. Our customers opinions have always been important to us, it was one of the reasons we become ACO organic. We started out as a very small-scale family business. We have always been a very family-run company. Even now, years later we still have our son and daughter working in the company. Along with our family values we are also very conscious of the impact manufacturing has on the wider community. We pride ourselves on sourcing sustainable and fair-trade ingredients and make sure to visit our plantations to ensure standards are upheld. In fact, one of our initiatives we set up for our plantation workers is to continue supporting them into retirement. Manufacturing COYO on the Sunshine Coast has been a pleasure. We have always had wonderful staff, easy access to major transport routes and a supportive community. The journey of COYO has been one Sandra and I couldn't imagine living without.
